<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 379, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|> 0625/52 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 260, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|> February/March 2022 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 644, 905, 840]]<|/det|>

<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the extension of a spring and use it to determine the weight of a metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 100, 413, 119]]<|/det|>
The spring has been set up for you.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 129, 410, 147]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 153, 740, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 371, 395, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[651, 371, 724, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 400, 144, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 821, 420]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the unstretched length \(l_0\) of the spring, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 429, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
<form>\(l_0 =\) ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 660, 478]]<|/det|>
Suspend the 1.0 N load from the spring, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 626, 507]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the stretched length \(l_{\mathrm{S}}\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 515, 920, 536]]<|/det|>
<form>\(l_{\mathrm{S}} =\) ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 530, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 146, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 920, 594]]<|/det|>
Suspend the metre rule from the spring using the hook fixed at the \(95.0 \text{cm}\) mark, as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
Place the other end of the metre rule so that the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark of the rule rests on the pivot. The metre rule must rest on the pivot at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark throughout the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 645, 895, 665]]<|/det|>
Place the load W on the metre rule with its centre at a distance \(d = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 845, 694]]<|/det|>
Ensure that the metre rule is horizontal by adjusting the clamp that holds the spring.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[67, 700, 928, 912]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 924, 534, 942]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 945, 549, 959]]<|/det|>
0625/52/F/M/22

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 902, 88]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring, as shown in Fig. 1.3. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 920, 135]]<|/det|> Repeat this procedure for distances \(d = 30.0 \text{cm}, d = 40.0 \text{cm}, d = 50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(d = 60.0 \text{cm}\) from the pivot. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 150, 541, 166]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 175, 601, 341]]<|/det|>
\(d/\mathrm {cm}\)\(l/\mathrm {cm}\)

40.0
50.0
60.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 342, 920, 359]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 146, 392]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 373, 848, 392]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(l/\mathrm{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(d/\mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis). Start the axes at the origin (0,0). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 400, 824, 826]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 829, 920, 848]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 861, 146, 880]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 861, 176, 880]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 861, 702, 880]]<|/det|> From your graph, determine \(L\), the value of \(l\) when \(d = 0.0 \mathrm{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 907, 920, 924]]<|/det|>
L = ........................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 907, 920, 924]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 71, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(W_{\mathrm{R}}\), the weight of the metre rule, using your value of \(L\) from \((\mathbf{d})(\mathbf{i})\), the values of \(l_{0}\) and \(l_{\mathrm{S}}\) from \((\mathbf{a})\) and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 116, 576, 153]]<|/det|>
\[W_{\mathrm{R}} = \frac{2(L - l_{0})}{(l_{\mathrm{S}} - l_{0})}\times k\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 164, 331, 183]]<|/det|>
where \(k = 1.0 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[536, 240, 920, 261]]<|/det|>
<form>W<sub>R</sub> = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 272, 180, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 272, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
It is sometimes difficult to position the load W on the scale of the metre rule at the correct distance \(d\) from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 317, 725, 338]]<|/det|>
Suggest **one** change to the apparatus to overcome this difficulty.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 411, 180, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 411, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
Suggest **one** possible source of inaccuracy other than the difficulty described in **(e)(i)**. Assume that the experiment is carried out carefully.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 518, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 752, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the thermal insulation properties of air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 680, 122]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1 and Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 435, 152]]<|/det|>
Beaker A is covered in thin black card.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
Beaker A is used on its own for the first part of the investigation and is placed inside beaker B for the second part of the investigation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[99, 191, 897, 377]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 390, 532, 409]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 144, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 422, 408, 440]]<|/det|>
Remove the lid from beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 437, 645, 456]]<|/det|>
Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and replace the lid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 453, 450, 471]]<|/det|>
Place the thermometer in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 920, 517]]<|/det|>
In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-clock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 920, 564]]<|/det|>
Record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(t = 60 \text{s}\), \(t = 90 \text{s}\), \(t = 120 \text{s}\), \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 761, 89]]<|/det|> Remove the thermometer and lid from beaker A and pour away the water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 920, 120]]<|/det|> Place beaker A inside beaker B, as shown in Fig. 2.2, so that there is an air gap between the sides of the two beakers. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 127, 730, 222]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 237, 534, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 268, 181, 286]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 268, 920, 301]]<|/det|> Repeat (a) for this arrangement, ensuring that the lid fits inside beaker B after pouring water into beaker A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 298, 920, 316]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 316, 181, 335]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 316, 581, 335]]<|/det|> Add units to the column headings in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 316, 920, 335]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 346, 541, 364]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 373, 742, 613]]<|/det|>
beaker Abeaker A inside beaker B
\(t/\)\(\theta /\)\(\theta /\)
0
30
60
90
120
150
180
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 631, 146, 650]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 631, 851, 650]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion stating whether the air gap affects the rate of cooling of the water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 647, 653, 666]]<|/det|> Justify your answer by reference to values from your results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 771, 920, 789]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 802, 148, 820]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 802, 920, 836]]<|/det|> A student suggests that glass is a thermal insulator and the experiment does not just test the effect of the air gap. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 848, 828, 866]]<|/det|> Suggest one change to the apparatus that would test the air gap more effectively. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 910, 920, 927]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 915, 91]]<|/det|>
Another student repeats the experiment using the apparatus you used for your investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
State two variables that this student should control to obtain readings as close as possible to your readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 917, 170]]<|/det|>
1. ..........................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 917, 230]]<|/det|>
2. ..........................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 257, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 143, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 287, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(R\) for beaker A cooling on its own. Use your readings for **beaker A** in Table 2.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 333, 556, 364]]<|/det|>
\[R = \frac{\theta_0 - \theta_{180}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker A at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 448, 431]]<|/det|>
Include the unit for the cooling rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 520, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 823, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light using a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 777, 120]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 435, 135]]<|/det|>
You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 144, 912, 616]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 630, 532, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 661, 144, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 661, 917, 693]]<|/det|>
Place the transparent block approximately in the centre of the ray-trace sheet. Carefully draw round the block and label the corners ABCD, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 692, 541, 707]]<|/det|>
Remove the block from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 707, 917, 739]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a point \(2\mathrm{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{A}\). Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\), as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 738, 814, 755]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{NE}\), \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta_{1} = 15^{\circ}\), as indicated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 754, 920, 771]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 785, 146, 802]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 785, 655, 802]]<|/det|>
Replace the block in exactly the same position as in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 801, 897, 816]]<|/det|>
Place the plane mirror on line CD with its face against the block, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 816, 910, 831]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line \(\mathbf{NE}\) a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 831, 500, 847]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 846, 917, 893]]<|/det|>
View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the block from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), a suitable distance apart so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), all appear exactly one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 892, 500, 908]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 907, 687, 924]]<|/det|>
Remove the block, mirror and pins from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 924, 920, 940]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 742, 91]]<|/det|>
Draw a line through \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and extend this line \(4\mathrm{cm}\) below \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 87, 688, 106]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{AB}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{G}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 103, 586, 122]]<|/det|>
Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 180, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 149, 893, 168]]<|/det|>
Draw a new line \(\mathbf{NE}\), \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta_2 = 35^\circ\), as indicated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 166, 430, 184]]<|/det|>
Repeat the steps in \((\mathbf{b})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 180, 920, 212]]<|/det|>
Draw a line joining the new positions of pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and extend this line \(4\mathrm{cm}\) below \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 211, 724, 229]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{AB}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{R}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 227, 621, 245]]<|/det|>
Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{S}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 242, 715, 261]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which \(\mathbf{GH}\) and \(\mathbf{RS}\) cross with the letter \(\mathbf{T}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 259, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 288, 181, 307]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 288, 762, 307]]<|/det|>
Measure the angle \(\beta\), where \(\beta\) is the angle between lines \(\mathbf{GT}\) and \(\mathbf{RT}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 333, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\beta =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 365, 181, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 365, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that the angle \(\beta\) should be equal to \(\theta_{\mathrm{s}}\), where \(\theta_{\mathrm{s}}\) is calculated using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 412, 551, 432]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{\mathrm{s}} = \theta_{2} - \theta_{1}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 443, 920, 477]]<|/det|>

justification .................................................................................................................

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 599, 144, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 599, 853, 618]]<|/det|>
Suggest one precaution to take in this type of experiment to ensure accurate results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 631, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<form>.................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 661, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 144, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why different students, all carrying out this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 797, 920, 816]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 800, 920, 818]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 846, 784, 865]]<|/det|>
Tie your ray-trace sheet into this booklet between pages 8 and 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 697, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the heating of water using an immersion heater.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 781, 104]]<|/det|>
An immersion heater is an electrical heater that can be placed directly into water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how **one** factor affects the rate at which the temperature of the water rises when heated using an immersion heater.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 520, 182]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 398, 213]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 331, 228]]<|/det|>
· an immersion heater

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 698, 244]]<|/det|>
· equipment to connect the circuit, part of which is shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 260, 259]]<|/det|>
· a stop-clock

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 259, 401, 275]]<|/det|>
· a beaker to contain the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 290, 324, 306]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 138, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 320, 920, 353]]<|/det|>
state the **one** factor which you have chosen and list any additional apparatus needed to measure the factor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 138, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 367, 477, 384]]<|/det|>
complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 134, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 399, 858, 415]]<|/det|>
explain how to do the experiment, including any precautions to ensure reliable results

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 429, 136, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 507, 446]]<|/det|>
state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 460, 136, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 507, 136, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 507, 606, 524]]<|/det|>
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
